title: Job Chapter 17 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Job chapter 17 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Job Chapter 17 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Job Chapter 17.

questions.question: According to Job 17:1, what is ready for Job?
questions.correctAnswer: The graves
questions.explanation: Job 17:1 states, "the graves are ready for me," indicating that the graves are prepared.

questions.question: In Job 17:2, who does Job say are with him?
questions.correctAnswer: Mockers
questions.explanation: Job 17:2 says, "Are there not mockers with me?" showing that mockers are with him.

questions.question: What does Job ask to be laid down with him in Job 17:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Surety
questions.explanation: In Job 17:3, Job says, "put me in a surety with thee," indicating he desires surety.

questions.question: According to Job 17:4, why will God not exalt certain people?
options: Because He has hid their heart from understanding
questions.correctAnswer: Because He has hid their heart from understanding
questions.explanation: Job 17:4 explains, "thou hast hid their heart from understanding: therefore shalt thou not exalt them."

questions.question: Who does Job say will fail if one speaks flattery to friends in Job 17:5?
questions.correctAnswer: The eyes of his children
questions.explanation: Job 17:5 states, "He that speaketh flattery to his friends, even the eyes of his children shall fail."

questions.question: True or False: Job 17:6 says that Job was like a tabret before becoming a byword of the people.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 17:6 says, "aforetime I was as a tabret," confirming Job’s previous condition.

questions.question: According to Job 17:7, what is dim by reason of sorrow?
questions.correctAnswer: Job's eye
questions.explanation: Job 17:7 states, "Mine eye also is dim by reason of sorrow."

questions.question: In Job 17:8, who shall be astonied at the situation?
questions.correctAnswer: Upright men
questions.explanation: Job 17:8 says, "Upright men shall be astonied at this."

questions.question: What shall the righteous do according to Job 17:9?
options: Hold on his way and be stronger and stronger
questions.correctAnswer: Hold on his way and be stronger and stronger
questions.explanation: Job 17:9 states, "The righteous also shall hold on his way... shall be stronger and stronger."

questions.question: What does Job say about finding a wise man among his listeners in Job 17:10?
options: He cannot find one wise man
He finds a few wise men
questions.correctAnswer: He cannot find one wise man
questions.explanation: Job 17:10 says, "I cannot find one wise man among you."

questions.question: True or False: Job 17:11 declares that Job’s days and purposes are complete and unbroken.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 17:11 says, "my days are past, my purposes are broken off," indicating they are incomplete.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Job 17:13: 'If I wait, the ______ is mine house.'
questions.correctAnswer: grave
questions.explanation: Job 17:13 states, "the grave is mine house."

questions.question: According to Job 17:14, to whom does Job say, 'Thou art my father'?
questions.correctAnswer: Corruption
questions.explanation: Job 17:14 says, "I have said to corruption, Thou art my father."

questions.question: According to Job 17:15, what question does Job ask about his hope?
questions.correctAnswer: Who shall see it?
questions.explanation: Job 17:15 says, "And where is now my hope? as for my hope, who shall see it?"

questions.question: True or False: Job 17:16 says that rest together is in the dust.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 17:16 states, "when our rest together is in the dust."

medium.title: Job Chapter 17 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Job Chapter 17 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and feels their strength fading. Based on Job 17:7, what biblical truth would you share about perseverance?
options: Sorrow can make us physically and spiritually weak, but God sees our struggle.
Trials have no effect on our inner strength if we trust God.
Physical weakness means we have failed in faith.
We should avoid sorrow to maintain spiritual strength.
questions.correctAnswer: Sorrow can make us physically and spiritually weak, but God sees our struggle.
questions.explanation: Job 17:7 speaks of the eye dim by reason of sorrow and members as a shadow, showing that trials affect us deeply, but the passage encourages honest recognition of weakness rather than denial, which is part of perseverance (Job 17:7; Job 17:1; Job 17:11).

questions.question: How does Job 17:9 teach us about integrity and spiritual growth in the midst of difficulties?
options: The righteous with clean hands grow stronger even during trials.
Only perfect people can grow stronger spiritually.
Spiritual growth depends on avoiding challenges.
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous with clean hands grow stronger even during trials.
questions.explanation: Job 17:9 highlights that those who are righteous and have clean hands will be stronger and stronger, emphasizing that integrity and faithfulness lead to spiritual growth despite hardships (Job 17:9; Job 17:8; Job 17:1).

questions.question: A believer struggles to find wise counsel among friends during hardship. What does Job 17:10 suggest about seeking wisdom?
options: Sometimes we may find no wise person nearby, but we must continue seeking God.
Friends always provide perfect wisdom in trials.
We should isolate ourselves when no wise counsel is found.
questions.correctAnswer: Sometimes we may find no wise person nearby, but we must continue seeking God.
questions.explanation: Job 17:10 laments the absence of a wise man among companions, suggesting that in hard times, human wisdom may fail, but faith calls for trust in God’s guidance beyond human counsel (Job 17:10; Job 17:3; Job 17:4).

questions.question: Considering Job 17:1, how does this verse teach us about humility and contentment in facing mortality?
options: Recognizing our fragile life encourages humility and reliance on God.
We should ignore thoughts about death to remain content.
Mortality means God has abandoned us.
Contentment comes from wealth and long life.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognizing our fragile life encourages humility and reliance on God.
questions.explanation: Job 17:1 speaks of breath corrupt and days extinct, reminding believers to be humble about life’s brevity and to depend on God’s sustaining grace (Job 17:1; Job 17:11; Job 17:15).

questions.question: How does Job 17:4 warn us about the danger of hardened hearts in spiritual understanding?
options: Hiding understanding leads to pride and prevents exaltation by God.
Hardened hearts are rewarded by God.
Understanding is not important in faith.
God exalts those who reject wisdom.
questions.correctAnswer: Hiding understanding leads to pride and prevents exaltation by God.
questions.explanation: Job 17:4 reveals that God hides understanding from some, resulting in their failure to be exalted, teaching that spiritual blindness leads to downfall (Job 17:4; Job 17:8; Job 17:9).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to flatter friends for personal gain. What warning does Job 17:5 provide?
options: Flattery harms relationships and even affects one’s own children adversely.
Flattery is a good way to build friendships.
Children always benefit from flattery directed at friends.
questions.correctAnswer: Flattery harms relationships and even affects one’s own children adversely.
questions.explanation: Job 17:5 warns that speaking flattery to friends results in even the eyes of one’s children failing, indicating the destructive nature of insincerity (Job 17:5; Job 17:6; Job 17:8).

questions.question: Based on Job 17:6, what spiritual lesson can be drawn about reputation during hardships?
options: Being made a byword can happen to faithful believers, but we must maintain our trust in God.
Reputation is more important than faithfulness.
Trials never affect how others view us.
questions.correctAnswer: Being made a byword can happen to faithful believers, but we must maintain our trust in God.
questions.explanation: Job 17:6 shows Job’s experience of being a byword among people, teaching believers to endure wrongful judgment while holding onto faith (Job 17:6; Job 17:7; Job 17:11).

questions.question: True or False: Job 17:15 expresses hope and confidence in seeing a future beyond suffering.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 17:15 questions where hope is now and who will see it, reflecting a moment of despair rather than confident hope (Job 17:15; Job 17:13; Job 17:16).

questions.question: How does Job 17:13 teach about facing death with faith?
options: Waiting on death is like making it a home, but faith can offer peace beyond darkness.
Death should be feared and avoided at all costs.
Ignoring death leads to stronger faith.
Death is meaningless and has no spiritual significance.
questions.correctAnswer: Waiting on death is like making it a home, but faith can offer peace beyond darkness.
questions.explanation: Job 17:13 describes the grave as a house and bed in darkness, teaching that while death is inevitable, believers are called to trust God’s ultimate deliverance (Job 17:13; Job 17:16; Job 17:15).

questions.question: A believer struggles with bitterness toward sin and corruption. What insight does Job 17:14 provide?
options: Corruption and decay are part of human mortality, but God’s mercy transcends this.
Corruption is a sign of God’s rejection.
We must ignore the reality of corruption to have faith.
questions.correctAnswer: Corruption and decay are part of human mortality, but God’s mercy transcends this.
questions.explanation: Job 17:14 personifies corruption and the worm as family, illustrating human frailty, teaching humility and the need for divine grace (Job 17:14; Job 17:1; Job 17:11).

questions.question: True or False: Job 17:8 suggests that upright and innocent people will be indifferent to hypocrisy.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 17:8 states that upright men are astonished and the innocent stir themselves against the hypocrite, showing active concern rather than indifference (Job 17:8; Job 17:9; Job 17:4).

questions.question: How does Job 17:3 express the importance of genuine fellowship and spiritual alliances?
options: Job desires a surety or binding agreement with a faithful companion, showing the need for trustworthy fellowship.
One should only rely on oneself in trials.
All spiritual alliances are risky and to be avoided.
questions.correctAnswer: Job desires a surety or binding agreement with a faithful companion, showing the need for trustworthy fellowship.
questions.explanation: In Job 17:3, Job asks for someone to strike hands with him, a metaphor for covenant or trusted companionship, emphasizing the biblical value of supportive relationships (Job 17:3; Job 17:10; Job 17:4).

questions.question: A Christian parent is concerned about raising children with integrity. What principle does Job 17:5 offer regarding speech and its impact on family?
options: Flattering speech harms not only friends but also children, stressing honesty in communication.
Parents’ speech has no effect on children.
Flattery is a useful tool in family relationships.
Children are unaffected by their parents’ words.
questions.correctAnswer: Flattering speech harms not only friends but also children, stressing honesty in communication.
questions.explanation: Job 17:5 shows that flattery to friends results in even children’s eyes failing, teaching that honesty and integrity in speech are critical for family well-being (Job 17:5; Job 17:6; Job 17:9).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Job 17:16, "They shall go down to the bars of the pit, when our rest together is in the _______."
questions.correctAnswer: dust
questions.explanation: Job 17:16 says our rest together is in the dust, referring to death and burial, illustrating the common destiny of humanity (Job 17:16; Job 17:13; Job 17:1).

questions.question: How does Job 17:12 describe the struggle between light and darkness, and what does it teach about spiritual perseverance?
options: The night turning into day but light being short teaches that even in hardship, we can find moments of hope amidst darkness.
Darkness always overcomes light, so perseverance is futile.
Light and darkness have no spiritual meaning.
Only darkness exists in trials, with no hope of light.
questions.correctAnswer: The night turning into day but light being short teaches that even in hardship, we can find moments of hope amidst darkness.
questions.explanation: Job 17:12 illustrates that night changes into day but light is brief because of darkness, symbolizing intermittent hope during trials, encouraging perseverance (Job 17:12; Job 17:7; Job 17:15).

hard.title: Job Chapter 17 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Job Chapter 17.

questions.question: In Job 17:1, Job describes his breath as 'corrupt' and his days as what?
questions.correctAnswer: Extinct
questions.explanation: Job 17:1 states, 'My breath is corrupt, my days are extinct,' indicating the end or cessation of his days.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Job 17:1 when Job says, 'the graves are ready for me'?
questions.correctAnswer: Personification
questions.explanation: The 'graves' are described as 'ready,' attributing human readiness to inanimate graves, a personification in Job 17:1.

questions.question: According to Job 17:3, Job asks, 'Lay down now, put me in a surety with thee.' What does 'surety' imply in the ancient Near Eastern context?
questions.correctAnswer: A guarantee or pledge
questions.explanation: In Job 17:3, 'surety' reflects a legal or social guarantee, showing Job’s desire for a binding agreement or support.

questions.question: Job 17:4 states, 'For thou hast hid their heart from understanding.' Who is 'thou' referring to, and what is the theological implication?
options: God, indicating divine sovereignty over human wisdom
The mocking people, signifying their blindness
questions.correctAnswer: God, indicating divine sovereignty over human wisdom
questions.explanation: 'Thou' refers to God, emphasizing His control over human understanding, as noted in Job 17:4.

questions.question: In Job 17:5, what consequence is mentioned for those who speak flattery to their friends?
options: The eyes of their children shall fail
questions.correctAnswer: The eyes of their children shall fail
questions.explanation: Job 17:5 warns that flattery leads to negative consequences, including the failure of children's eyes, symbolizing loss or judgment.

questions.question: True or False: In Job 17:7, Job describes his eye as bright and full of hope despite his sorrow.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 17:7 states, 'Mine eye also is dim by reason of sorrow,' indicating diminished hope and vitality.

questions.question: How does Job 17:8 contrast the reactions of upright men and the innocent toward the hypocrite?
options: Upright men are astonished; the innocent stir themselves against the hypocrite
The hypocrite is praised by upright men
questions.correctAnswer: Upright men are astonished; the innocent stir themselves against the hypocrite
questions.explanation: Job 17:8 states that upright men are amazed, while the innocent actively oppose the hypocrite, highlighting moral awareness.

questions.question: What does Job say about the righteous and those with clean hands in Job 17:9?
options: They shall be stronger and stronger
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be stronger and stronger
questions.explanation: Job 17:9 assures that the righteous and pure will continue to grow in strength, showing a theme of moral perseverance.

questions.question: In Job 17:10, Job states he cannot find one what among his companions?
questions.correctAnswer: Wise man
questions.explanation: Job 17:10 laments the lack of wisdom among his peers, highlighting his isolation and the failure of his friends.

questions.question: Job 17:11 speaks of broken purposes and thoughts. What does this reveal about Job’s emotional state?
questions.correctAnswer: Despair and loss of hope
questions.explanation: The verse reveals deep despair as Job’s plans and inner thoughts are shattered, showing his emotional turmoil.

questions.question: Job 17:12 uses the imagery 'They change the night into day: the light is short because of darkness.' This is an example of what literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Paradox
questions.explanation: The statement contrasts night and day simultaneously, a paradox that expresses confusion and reversal of natural order.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Job 17:13: 'If I wait, the grave is mine ______: I have made my bed in the darkness.'
questions.correctAnswer: house
questions.explanation: Job 17:13 uses 'house' to symbolize the grave as a dwelling place of death and final rest.

questions.question: In Job 17:14, Job personifies corruption and the worm by calling them what familial relations?
questions.correctAnswer: Father, mother, and sister
questions.explanation: Job 17:14 assigns intimate family roles to corruption and the worm, emphasizing intimacy with death and decay.

questions.question: What is the tone of Job's question in Job 17:15: 'And where is now my hope?'
questions.correctAnswer: Desperate and hopeless
questions.explanation: The rhetorical question signifies deep despair and loss of hope in Job 17:15.

questions.question: According to Job 17:16, where will Job and those like him rest together?
questions.correctAnswer: In the dust
questions.explanation: Job 17:16 mentions resting together 'in the dust,' a common biblical metaphor for death and burial.

theological.title: Job Chapter 17 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Job Chapter 17 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Job 17:1, what condition does Job describe about his life?
options: My breath is corrupt, my days are extinct, the graves are ready for me
I am surrounded by friends who comfort me
My health is strong and my days are many
I find great joy in my work and family
questions.correctAnswer: My breath is corrupt, my days are extinct, the graves are ready for me
questions.explanation: Job 17:1 explicitly states Job's condition of despair: 'My breath is corrupt, my days are extinct, the graves are ready for me.' This reflects a deep human experience of mortality and suffering consistent with Psalm 103:3-4, Ecclesiastes 3:2, Romans 5:12, and James 4:14.

questions.question: In Job 17:3, what does Job request regarding his relationship with God?
options: Lay down now, put me in a surety with thee; who is he that will strike hands with me?
Bless me with long life and prosperity
Grant me wisdom to judge my friends
Remove my afflictions and restore my health
questions.correctAnswer: Lay down now, put me in a surety with thee; who is he that will strike hands with me?
questions.explanation: Job 17:3 reveals Job’s plea for divine assurance or a covenantal relationship ('put me in a surety with thee'), highlighting the human longing for divine solidarity amid suffering, paralleling covenant themes in Genesis 15:18, Isaiah 54:10, Hebrews 6:17-18, and 2 Corinthians 1:20.

questions.question: What does Job say about God’s knowledge of the hearts of men in Job 17:4?
options: For thou hast hid their heart from understanding: therefore shalt thou not exalt them
God fully reveals the hearts of all men
The hearts of men are always transparent to God
God ignores the hearts of sinners
questions.correctAnswer: For thou hast hid their heart from understanding: therefore shalt thou not exalt them
questions.explanation: Job 17:4 indicates that God withholds understanding from some, preventing their exaltation, reflecting divine sovereignty and judgment, consistent with 1 Corinthians 2:14, Romans 1:28, Proverbs 21:2, and Psalm 94:11.

questions.question: According to Job 17:5, what is the consequence for those who flatter their friends?
options: Even the eyes of his children shall fail
They will gain wisdom and honor
questions.correctAnswer: Even the eyes of his children shall fail
questions.explanation: Job 17:5 warns that flattery leads to ruin affecting even one’s offspring, illustrating the destructive impact of deceit, as echoed in Proverbs 26:28, Psalm 12:2, 2 Timothy 3:13, and Jeremiah 9:5.

questions.question: In Job 17:6, how does Job describe his current reputation among the people?
options: He hath made me also a byword of the people; and aforetime I was as a tabret
He is honored and respected by all
He is regarded as a wise teacher
questions.correctAnswer: He hath made me also a byword of the people; and aforetime I was as a tabret
questions.explanation: Job 17:6 reveals Job’s lament that he has become a proverb or object of ridicule, contrasting with his former joyful existence ('as a tabret'), reflecting themes of social disgrace found in Psalm 22:6, Proverbs 3:34, Isaiah 53:3, and Matthew 27:39.

questions.question: What physical and emotional conditions does Job describe in Job 17:7?
options: Mine eye also is dim by reason of sorrow, and all my members are as a shadow
My body is strong and my heart is joyful
My eyes see clearly and my spirit is uplifted
I am full of energy and hope
questions.correctAnswer: Mine eye also is dim by reason of sorrow, and all my members are as a shadow
questions.explanation: Job 17:7 describes Job’s physical and emotional decline, emphasizing sorrow’s effect on his eyes and body, paralleling lament expressions found in Psalm 6:7, Lamentations 3:17, Isaiah 38:10, and 2 Corinthians 4:16.

questions.question: In Job 17:8, who are said to be astonished by Job’s situation?
options: Upright men shall be astonied at this, and the innocent shall stir up himself against the hypocrite
Only the wicked laugh at Job
The kings and rulers are indifferent
Job’s friends rejoice in his downfall
questions.correctAnswer: Upright men shall be astonied at this, and the innocent shall stir up himself against the hypocrite
questions.explanation: Job 17:8 shows that righteous people are shocked by injustice and hypocrisy, highlighting the moral awareness of the upright, consistent with Proverbs 29:7, Psalm 34:14, Isaiah 1:17, and Romans 12:17.

questions.question: What does Job declare about the righteous man in Job 17:9?
options: The righteous also shall hold on his way, and he that hath clean hands shall be stronger and stronger
The righteous will fall into despair
The righteous are ignored and forgotten
The righteous will be weak and defeated
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous also shall hold on his way, and he that hath clean hands shall be stronger and stronger
questions.explanation: Job 17:9 affirms that righteousness leads to perseverance and increasing strength, echoing themes in Psalm 1:3, Proverbs 10:29, Isaiah 40:31, and Philippians 4:13.

questions.question: In Job 17:10, what does Job lament about the people around him?
options: I cannot find one wise man among you
They are all wise and understanding
They comfort me in my affliction
questions.correctAnswer: I cannot find one wise man among you
questions.explanation: Job 17:10 expresses Job’s disappointment over the lack of wisdom among his peers, highlighting human folly, consistent with Ecclesiastes 7:5, Proverbs 1:7, Jeremiah 4:22, and 1 Corinthians 1:20.

questions.question: What does Job say about his days and purposes in Job 17:11?
options: My days are past, my purposes are broken off, even the thoughts of my heart
My days are long and my purposes are fulfilled
My heart is full of hope and plans
questions.correctAnswer: My days are past, my purposes are broken off, even the thoughts of my heart
questions.explanation: Job 17:11 reflects the theme of human frailty and the brokenness of plans, consistent with Psalm 31:15, Jeremiah 29:11, Proverbs 16:9, and James 4:13-15.

questions.question: How does Job describe the transition of time in Job 17:12?
options: They change the night into day: the light is short because of darkness
Day and night continue in perfect order
The night is long and the day is full of light
Darkness is overcome by eternal light
questions.correctAnswer: They change the night into day: the light is short because of darkness
questions.explanation: Job 17:12 uses metaphorical language about darkness and light to express confusion and despair, paralleling Genesis 1:4, Isaiah 9:2, John 1:5, and 2 Corinthians 4:6.

questions.question: What does Job say about his relationship with the grave in Job 17:13?
options: If I wait, the grave is mine house: I have made my bed in the darkness
I will overcome death and live forever
The grave is a distant place I fear not
I have no concern for death
questions.correctAnswer: If I wait, the grave is mine house: I have made my bed in the darkness
questions.explanation: Job 17:13 illustrates Job’s resignation to death and the grave as his dwelling, reflecting biblical realism about mortality, consistent with Ecclesiastes 12:5-7, Psalm 88:3-6, Isaiah 38:18, and Hebrews 9:27.

questions.question: In Job 17:14, how does Job personify corruption and worms?
options: I have said to corruption, Thou art my father: to the worm, Thou art my mother, and my sister
Corruption and worms are enemies to be feared
Corruption and worms will be destroyed forever
Corruption and worms are distant and unknown
questions.correctAnswer: I have said to corruption, Thou art my father: to the worm, Thou art my mother, and my sister
questions.explanation: Job 17:14 uses poetic personification to express Job’s intimate identification with decay and death, consistent with Genesis 3:19, Psalm 22:6, Isaiah 41:14, and Romans 8:22.

questions.question: What question does Job ask concerning his hope in Job 17:15?
options: And where is now my hope? as for my hope, who shall see it?
Will my hope bring me riches and honor?
Does my hope depend on the favor of men?
Can my hope be hidden from God?
questions.correctAnswer: And where is now my hope? as for my hope, who shall see it?
questions.explanation: Job 17:15 expresses Job’s despair about the loss of hope, highlighting existential questions that resonate with Psalm 39:7, Lamentations 3:21-24, Romans 15:13, and Hebrews 6:19.

questions.question: What does Job say about the fate of those who die in Job 17:16?
options: They shall go down to the bars of the pit, when our rest together is in the dust
They ascend immediately to the heavens
They are reborn in a new life
questions.correctAnswer: They shall go down to the bars of the pit, when our rest together is in the dust
questions.explanation: Job 17:16 speaks to the finality of death and the common grave, consistent with Ecclesiastes 3:20, Psalm 49:15, Daniel 12:2, and John 5:28-29.
